perturbation.original_text:
Supplier agrees that no production or manufacture of any merchandise covered by this Contract will commence until this Contract has been signed, dated and returned by Supplier to Purchaser. Supplier further agrees that it will not produce, 
cause to be produced or assist in the production of more units than are specified by Purchaser nor will Supplier produce,
cause to be produced or assist in the production of any product or item not specifically requested by Purchaser using any 
or all of the Playboy Properties or any trademark, copyright, designations, names, phrases, designs or symbols similar to 
any or all of the Playboy Properties during or at any time after the completion of merchandise requested by this Contract.
perturbation.changed_text:
Supplier agrees that production or manufacture of any merchandise covered by this Contract may commence before this Contract has been signed, dated and returned by Supplier to Purchaser. Supplier further agrees that it will produce, 
cause to be produced or assist in the production of more units than are specified by Purchaser and will produce,
cause to be produced or assist in the production of any product or item not specifically requested by Purchaser using any 
or all of the Playboy Properties or any trademark, copyright, designations, names, phrases, designs or symbols similar to 
any or all of the Playboy Properties during or at any time after the completion of merchandise requested by this Contract.
perturbation.explanation: This change removes the requirement for the contract to be fully executed before production begins, creating potential intellectual property risks, and enabling unauthorized overproduction or misuse of Playboy's intellectual property after the contract has ended, which are in direct conflict with copyright and trademark laws. It also removes a crucial control mechanism to protect the trademark and allows for potential production beyond the terms of the agreement.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Trademark Act of 1946 (Lanham Act) and Copyright Act

perturbation.original_text:
Supplier will, upon request from Purchaser or Playboy, deliver to Purchaser or will destroy in the presence of Purchaser
or its representative(s), all molds, designs or any other elements used in reproducing any or all of the Playboy Properties.
perturbation.changed_text: Supplier will, upon request from Purchaser, deliver to Purchaser or destroy at their discretion, all molds, designs or any other elements used in reproducing any or all of the Playboy Properties, with no oversight.
perturbation.explanation: This change removes the mandatory presence of the Purchaser or its representative during the destruction of molds, designs, etc. Allowing the supplier to destroy these items at their discretion and without oversight opens the door to potential misuse or unauthorized retention of materials used to reproduce the Playboy Properties, contradicting trademark and copyright protection measures. This weakens the protection of Playboy's intellectual property rights. The absence of oversight directly clashes with the necessary protection against counterfeiting.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Trademark Act of 1946 (Lanham Act) and Copyright Act

perturbation.original_text:
This Contract may not be modified or terminated except in writing, and no claimed modification, termination or waiver 
shall be binding unless also signed by an authorized representative of Playboy.
perturbation.changed_text: This Contract may be modified or terminated verbally, and any modification, termination or waiver shall be binding without the signature of an authorized representative of Playboy.
perturbation.explanation: This modification allows for verbal changes to the contract and removes the requirement for Playboy's authorized signature for any changes, termination, or waiver to be binding. This contradicts fundamental contract law principles, specifically the Statute of Frauds (in many jurisdictions), which requires certain agreements, particularly those involving significant intellectual property rights, to be in writing to be enforceable. This makes the contract much more difficult to enforce and opens it up to potential disputes and misinterpretations. The change from written consent to verbal agreement directly contradicts standard business practices.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Statute of Frauds and general contract law principles
